passages.text: Foreign Exchange - Global
Key events next week: The LDP's joint plenary meeting, BOJ Deputy Governor's speech, and the US jobs report

The volatility of USD/JPY in August was fairly limited, after the US NFP's release at the start of the month. Headed into its August print next Friday, we stay short USD/JPY, as we maintain our view that the pair's risk is skewed to the downside. The likelihood of an early LDP leadership election has likely eased, owing to the party election committee's decision on voting process. However, Secretary General Moriyama's resignation could trigger an early election, and the situation remains fluid. The OIS market's pricing for the BOJ's rate hike by this year-end has not changed around 16- 17bp, while BOJspeak has not downplayed that pricing this week, likely owing to Japan's inflationary pressure being resilient. JPY week ahead: US nonfarm payrolls is the key focus next week. The LDP is scheduled to hold a general assembly to review the Upper House election outcome and then, the opinion- gathering process on an early leadership election will commence. BOJ Deputy Governor Himino is scheduled to speak.

Following its significant fall on 1 August (i.e., following the US jobs report release), USD/JPY has been moving within its tight range around 147. While Powell's dovish pivot at the Jackson Hole Symposium and President Trump politicizing the Fed have been factors that led us to remain bearish on the USD, there has been a lack of follow- through in the currency's movement to its downside. This could be due to US macroeconomic data continuing to show positive surprises to some extent, as per Bloomberg's economic surprise index (Fig. 1).

Consequently, we expect the direction of USD/JPY is likely to highly hinge on the next US jobs report for August due next Friday. Our US economics team forecasts the payrolls to increase by 85k m- o- m and unemployment to tick up by 0.1pp to \(4.3\%\) .

Considering these data- outturn are unlikely to be sufficient in proving that the US labor market is softening, a rapid pace, we believe the likelihood of the market's pricing for a 50bp cut by the Fed in September won't increase much (Fig. 2). Nevertheless, as Fed Governor Waller (on 28 August) briefly indicated a 50bp cut in September is an option for his voting, we believe the USD/JPY movement will be asymmetrically skewed to the downside. Therefore, into the US tier- 1 data next week, we retain our short USD/JPY targeting 142 by end- October.
Fig. 1: US economic surprise index and USD/JPY
Source:Bloomberg, Nomura
Fig. 2: USD/JPY and the market-implied Fed policy rate
Source:Bloomberg,Nomura

With respect to JPY- specific factors, domestic politics remain the market's main focus, as the global bond yield curves have further steepened in August, with Japan's 10s30s government bond yield spread still extended at 156bp, even after its significant steepening in this April.

In our view, the likelihood of an early LDP leadership election has decreased more than what the market had previously anticipated, as the latest decision by the LDP's presidential election management committee likely raised the psychological hurdle for LDP lawmakers to call for the interim presidential election. Namely, LDP Diet lawmakers and prefectural party branches that prefer to hold an early presidential election will be required to submit their views with their names included, by 3pm JST, on a designated date between five and seven days after 2 September, when the party is scheduled to release their assessment on 2025 Upper House election results.

To be clear, we are not arguing that we hold a strong view on the probability of whether an early leadership election will be held anytime soon. We would frame that the LDP lawmakers and prefectural party branches may have now been discouraged to be strongly vocal about the early election, and the risk of Prime Minister Ishiba resigning early has not been entirely ruled out.

Another key aspect we are closely monitoring regarding the early LDP leadership election case is the scenario that LDP's Secretary General Moriyama potentially resigns. Should Moriyama resign, it could become challenging for the Prime Minister to remain in his position. This is because, if Ishiba stays as the LDP leader, this is likely to be negatively construed by the public, and could be reflected in the lower Cabinet supporting rate. Thus, Moriyama's resignation could be a trigger for the political instability risk to increase.

Further complicating the situation, the likelihood of Moriyama's resignation is also unclear at this juncture. In late July (i.e., soon after the election), Moriyama suggested that he might resign to take responsibility for the national election losses. However, recent media reports (e.g, Mainichi) have been unclear with regard to whether he maintains this intention of stepping down. In addition, on 20 August, he was confirmed to continue as Chairman of the Kagoshima Prefecture chapter, despite his intention to resign from that role, as his supporters favored him to stay. He also did not provide any new information following the party's Upper House election result review meeting on 29 August.
Therefore, to summarize, as we head into the LDP's publication of Upper House election assessment report on 2 September, we will closely monitor two aspects to better gauge

the probability of an early LDP presidential election: 1) whether LDP lawmakers will remain vocal about holding the election; and 2) whether Secretary General Moriyama will decide to step down from his position. These developments could influence Japan's cabinet supporting rates and LDP's supporting rate, thus the need to be followed as well (Fig. 3, Fig. 4).
Fig. 3: Japan's cabinet job approval rating
Source: Yomiuri, Mainichi, Nikkei, Kyodo, JNN, Asahi, ANN, NHK, Sankei, Jiji, Nomura
Fig. 4: Supporting rate by Japanese political party (NHK survey)
Source: Macrobond, Nomura

Meanwhile, consensus for the market's pricing on the BOJ's rate hike has not changed much in the past weeks. Market economists' consensus, according to Bloomberg, is that the next 25bp hike by the BOJ will be delivered in Q4 2025; however, the OIS market's pricing for the BOJ's additional hike by end- 2025 has been almost flat at 16- 17bp.

Nonetheless, the BOJ policy board members are not necessarily dovish with respect to its policy rate outlook. Governor Ueda, in his speech at the Jackson Hole Symposium, expressed his view that wage pressures in Japan are likely to persist absent a significant negative demand shock. In addition, another policy board member, Nakagawa, briefly said that the environment for a rate hike has improved somewhat compared with April (source: Bloomberg). As Nakagawa emphasized her data- dependant approach, we would not place too much importance on her comment above, while we believe it's fair to say the BOJ's October 2025 MPM is a live meeting.

The likely rationale behind BOJ policy board members not pushing back the market's expectation of the next hike by this year- end is that the inflationary pressure in Japan remains resilient. This week, we had Japan's underlying inflation data (for July) released by the BOJ, which provided less support for a near- term BOJ rate hike (Fig. 5). However, services PPI data (for July) were not as weak as the headline figure indicated, as PPI for services with a high labor cost ratio remained resilient. Moreover, in the Tokyo CPI report (for August), services CPI inflation remained steady around 2% annual increase (Fig. 6), and this supports the BOJ's view that Japanese companies' price and wage setting behavior are changing.
Fig. 5: BOJ's measures of underlying inflation

Note: Note: 1. The share of increasing/decreasing items is the share of items in the CPI (less fresh food) whose price indices increased/decreased from a year earlier. 2. Dotted lines show when base year changed for this statistics. Source: Macrobond, Nomura
Fig. 6: Tokyo CPI inflation by category
Source: Macrobond, Nomura

USD/JPY forecast range: 145.00- 150.00USD/JPY has continued to exhibit subdued movement around the 147 level. Following Fed Chair Powell's speech at the Jackson Hole symposium, market expectations that the Fed will resume rate cuts at the September FOMC meeting have risen further. However, the market's primary focus remains on US economic data, particularly the upcoming employment report. It will be crucial to see whether these indicators further bolster expectations for more aggressive US rate cuts. Political developments in Japan and France, as well as the situation in Ukraine, also warrant attention. Overall, next week's USD/JPY trends are likely to hinge on the US NFP, with subdued movement expected in the early part of the week as investors await key data releases.

In Japan, the ruling LDP is scheduled to hold a review of the Upper House election results at a general assembly on Tuesday. Depending on the decisions of the party leadership about the possible resignation, including Secretary General Moriyama, pressure on PM Ishiba to step down could intensify. Even if the assembly passes without major political moves, an opinion- gathering process on whether to hold an early leadership election is expected to commence, suggesting that political uncertainty will likely persist in the near term. BOJ Deputy Governor Himino is also slated to speak on 2 September; however, with limited prospects for a rate hike at the upcoming September BOJ meeting, market reactions may remain muted. On the data front, attention will turn to Japan's monthly labour earnings scheduled for release on Friday.

In the US, the spotlight will be on the employment report scheduled for Friday. The July NFP, which included downward revisions to previous months, significantly increased concerns around the US economic outlook. Market consensus currently forecasts a 80k increase in NFP for August, comparable to July's 73k gain. Our US economics team's forecast is slightly higher at 85k. Should the actual figures fall within this range, concerns over a sharp economic slowdown may not intensify, thereby reinforcing the prevailing baseline scenario of a 25bp cut in September. Conversely, a disappointing report could reignite speculation of a larger 50b cut at the September FOMC, potentially triggering heightened volatility in the currency markets.

Other key US data releases ahead of the employment report include the ISM Manufacturing Index on Tuesday, and the ISM Services Index on Thursday, which will provide insight into business conditions and inflationary pressures following the recent tariff hikes in August. Attention will also focus on information flows before the blackout period ahead of the FOMC meeting, such as the Beige Book on Wednesday, and remarks from NY Fed President Williams on Thursday. In addition, reports indicate that Treasury Secretary Bessent is scheduled to meet with a candidate for Fed Chair around Labor Day on Monday, hence related headlines should also be monitored closely.
Fig.9:Week ahead events calendar

Note: Time stamps are all London time. Source: Bloomberg, Nomura
MOF international weekly capital flow data (from 17 to 23 August)

Japanese equity: Overseas investors net sold JPY496.8n (\$3.4bn) of Japanese equities for the first time in nine weeks. During the week, Japanese stocks, which had been in an upward trend, showed signs of peaking. It appears that overseas investors sold Japanese stocks to take profits.

Japanese bonds: Overseas investors net sold JPY106.0bn (\$0.7bn) of Japanese long- term debt. As we can see from the Z- score scale, the magnitude of their net sales were tiny compared to their past activities.
Fig.10: Weekly MOF international transactions in securities (as of 17 to 23 August)

and taxes in the case of a sale) (for transaction amounts of \(\yen 750,000\) and below, maximum domestic sales commission is \(\yen 7,810\) (tax included)). Local fees and taxes in foreign financial instruments markets vary by country/territory. When foreign equities are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Foreign equities carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as price fluctuations and foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

Margin transactions are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.43\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(\yen 2,860\) (tax included) for transactions of \(\yen 200,000\) or less), as well as management fees and rights handling fees. In addition, long margin transactions are subject to interest on the purchase amount, while short margin transactions are subject to fees for the lending of the shares borrowed. A margin equal to at least \(30\%\) of the transaction amount (at least \(33\%\) for online transactions) and at least \(\yen 300,000\) is required. With margin transactions, an amount up to roughly \(3.3x\) the margin (roughly \(3x\) for online transactions) may be traded. Margin transactions therefore carry the risk of losses in excess of the margin owing to share price fluctuations. For details, please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as listed securities documents or documents delivered before making a contract.

Transactions involving convertible bonds are subject to a sales commission of up to \(1.10\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount (or a commission of \(\yen 4,400\) (tax included) if this would be less than \(\yen 4,400\) ). When convertible bonds are purchased via OTC transactions (including offerings), only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. However, Nomura Securities may charge a separate fee for OTC transactions, as agreed with the customer. Convertible bonds carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as interest rate fluctuations and price fluctuations in the underlying stock. In addition, convertible bonds denominated in foreign currencies also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When bonds are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions, or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Bonds carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates. Bond prices may also fall below the invested principal as a result of such factors as changes in the management and financial circumstances of the issuer, or changes in third- party valuations of the bond in question. In addition, foreign currency- denominated bonds also carry the risk of losses owing to factors such as foreign exchange rate fluctuations.

When Japanese government bonds (JGBs) for individual investors are purchased via public offerings, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. As a rule, JGBs for individual investors may not be sold in the first 12 months after issuance. When JGBs for individual investors are sold before maturity, an amount calculated via the following formula will be subtracted from the par value of the bond plus accrued interest: (1) for 10- year variable rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) \(\times 0.79685\) will be used, (2) for 5- year and 3- year fixed rate bonds, an amount equal to the two preceding coupon payments (before tax) \(\times 0.79685\) will be used. When inflation- indexed JGBs are purchased via public offerings, secondary distributions (uridashi deals), or other OTC transactions with Nomura Securities, only the purchase price shall be paid, with no sales commission charged. Inflation- indexed JGBs carry the risk of losses, as prices fluctuate in line with changes in market interest rates and fluctuations in the nationwide consumer price index. The notional principal of inflation- indexed JGBs changes in line with the rate of change in nationwide CPI inflation from the time of its issuance. The amount of the coupon payment is calculated by multiplying the coupon rate by the notional principal at the time of payment. The maturity value is the amount of the notional principal when the issue becomes due. For J117 and subsequent issues, the maturity value shall not undercut the face amount. Purchases of investment trusts (and sales of some investment trusts) are subject to a purchase or sales fee of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included) of the transaction amount. Also, a direct cost that may be incurred when selling investment trusts is a fee of up to \(2.0\%\) of the unit price at the time of redemption. Indirect costs that may be incurred during the course of holding investment trusts include, for domestic investment trusts, an asset management fee (trust fee) of up to \(5.5\%\) (tax included/annualized basis) of the net assets in trust, as well as fees based on investment performance. Other indirect costs may also be incurred. For foreign investment trusts, indirect fees may be incurred during the course of holding such as investment company compensation.

Investment trusts invest mainly in securities such as Japanese and foreign equities and bonds, whose prices fluctuate. Investment trust unit prices fluctuate owing to price fluctuations in the underlying assets and to foreign exchange rate fluctuations. As such, investment trusts carry the risk of losses. Fees and risks vary by investment trust. Maximum applicable fees are subject to change; please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as prospectuses or documents delivered before making a contract.

In interest rate swap transactions and USD/JPY basis swap transactions ("interest rate swap transactions, etc."), only the agreed transaction payments shall be made on the settlement dates. Some interest rate swap transactions, etc. may require pledging of margin collateral. In some of these cases, transaction payments may exceed the amount of collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the transaction. Interest rate swap transactions, etc. carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in market prices in the interest rate, currency and other markets, as well as reference indices. Losses incurred as such may exceed the value of margin collateral, in which case margin calls may be triggered. In the event that both parties agree to enter a replacement (or termination) transaction, the interest rates received (paid) under the new arrangement may differ from those in the original arrangement, even if terms other than the interest rates are identical to those in the original transaction. Risks vary by transaction. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract and disclosure statements.

In OTC transactions of credit default swaps (CDS), no sales commission will be charged. When entering into CDS transactions, the protection buyer will be required to pledge or entrust an agreed amount of margin collateral. In some of these cases, the transaction payments may exceed the amount of margin collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the financial position of the protection buyer. CDS transactions carry the risk of losses owing to changes in the credit position of some or all of the referenced entities, and/or fluctuations of the interest rate market. The amount the protection buyer receives in the event that the CDS is triggered by a credit event may undercut the total amount of premiums that he/she has paid in the course of the transaction. Similarly, the amount the protection seller pays in the event of a credit event may exceed the total amount of premiums that he/she has received in the transaction. All other conditions being equal, the amount of premiums that the protection buyer pays and that received by the protection seller shall differ. In principle, CDS transactions will be limited to financial instruments business operators and qualified institutional investors. Transfers of equities to another securities company via the Japan Securities Depository Center are subject to a transfer fee of up to \(\yen 11,000\) (tax included) per issue transferred depending on volume. No account fee will be charged for marketable securities or monies deposited.
